questions.question: According to the 'CEO Mindset' framework in Lesson 1, what is the primary indicator that a practitioner has successfully transitioned to a business owner?
options: The practitioner is working 60+ hours per week to ensure client satisfaction.
The business can generate revenue and maintain service quality without the owner's daily involvement in delivery.
The practitioner has increased their hourly rate by at least 50% from the previous year.
The business has moved from a home office to a commercial retail space.
questions.explanation: The CEO mindset focuses on 'working on' the business rather than 'in' it. Success is defined by building systems and teams that allow the business to scale independently of the founder's time.

questions.question: When scaling the P.E.R.F.O.R.M. Methodology™ for teams (Lesson 2), which strategy is most effective for maintaining individualization within a group setting?
options: Providing the exact same meal plan to every athlete on the team to ensure consistency.
Using 'Tiered Programming' where athletes are grouped by physiological needs or positional demands.
Eliminating the 'Evaluation' phase of the methodology to save time during group onboarding.
Requiring athletes to seek outside help for any specific nutritional adjustments.
questions.explanation: Tiered programming allows the P.E.R.F.O.R.M. Methodology™ to scale by addressing the common needs of subgroups (e.g., linemen vs. wide receivers) while maintaining a level of specificity.

questions.question: Lesson 3 discusses Advanced Technology Integration. What is the 'Data Silo' problem, and how does a scaling business solve it?
options: Having too much data; solved by deleting 50% of client records every quarter.
Data being trapped in disconnected apps (wearables, food logs, CRM); solved by using API integrations and a centralized dashboard.
Data being too accessible to competitors; solved by removing all cloud-based storage.
Data being too expensive to collect; solved by switching to manual paper tracking.
questions.explanation: Data silos occur when information is fragmented across different platforms. Scaling businesses use integration (APIs) to create a 'Single Source of Truth' for athlete performance data.

questions.question: In the context of High-Ticket Offer Engineering (Lesson 4), what is the primary difference between 'Value-Based Pricing' and 'Commodity Pricing'?
options: Value-based pricing is always cheaper than commodity pricing to attract more volume.
Commodity pricing is based on the results achieved, while value-based is based on hours worked.
Value-based pricing is based on the perceived and actual ROI for the athlete, while commodity pricing is based on market averages for time.
There is no difference; the terms are used interchangeably in sports nutrition.
questions.explanation: Value-based pricing decouples time from money, focusing on the economic or performance impact of the transformation (e.g., securing a professional contract) rather than an hourly rate.

questions.question: Lesson 5 covers Strategic Partnerships. Which of the following represents a 'B2B Growth Model' for a Sports Nutrition Coach?
options: Selling a single protein powder tub to a local gym member.
Contracting with a professional soccer academy to provide nutritional oversight for their entire roster on a retainer basis.
Posting a transformation photo on Instagram to attract individual clients.
Offering a 10% discount to friends and family.
questions.explanation: The B2B (Business to Business) model involves selling services to organizations (academies, teams, corporations) rather than individual consumers (B2C), allowing for larger contracts and more stable revenue.

questions.question: According to Lesson 6, what is the 'Ancillary Revenue' benefit of digital products like 'The Off-Season Fueling Guide'?
options: It requires the coach to spend 1-on-1 time with every person who buys it.
It serves as a 'low-friction' entry point into the coach's ecosystem, often yielding 70-90% profit margins after development.
It is the only way to make money in sports nutrition.
It replaces the need for high-ticket coaching entirely.
questions.explanation: Digital products provide high-margin, scalable revenue that introduces clients to your methodology without requiring additional time for delivery.

questions.question: When building a team (Lesson 7), the '70% Rule' for delegation states that:
options: You should only delegate a task if the employee can do it 100% as well as you.
You should delegate a task if an employee can perform it at least 70% as well as you could.
Employees should only work 70% of the time to avoid burnout.
You should keep 70% of the profit and pay the team 30%.
questions.explanation: The 70% Rule is a leadership principle used to overcome the 'perfectionism trap,' allowing the CEO to delegate tasks even if the execution isn't initially identical to their own, facilitating business growth.

questions.question: Lesson 8 discusses Authority Marketing. Which component is essential for moving from 'General Practitioner' to 'Recognized Authority'?
options: Having the lowest prices in the local area.
A consistent 'Omnichannel' content strategy that demonstrates proprietary methodology and thought leadership.
Avoiding all social media to maintain an air of mystery.
Copying the marketing strategies of the largest supplement companies exactly.
questions.explanation: Authority is built through the consistent demonstration of expertise and a unique methodology (like P.E.R.F.O.R.M.™) across multiple platforms where your target audience resides.

questions.question: A key business metric mentioned in the module is the LTV:CAC ratio. If a client's Lifetime Value (LTV) is $3,000 and the Cost Per Acquisition (CAC) is $500, what is the ratio and what does it indicate?
options: 1:6; the business is failing and should stop all marketing.
6:1; the business is highly efficient and has significant room to scale marketing spend.
3:1; this is the bare minimum for survival.
1:1; the business is breaking even on every client.
questions.explanation: A 6:1 ratio ($3,000 / $500) indicates high efficiency. Generally, a 3:1 ratio is considered the 'gold standard' for healthy growth in service-based businesses.

questions.question: In a B2B case study from Lesson 5, a coach partners with a local CrossFit box. Instead of individual coaching, they offer a 'Challenge' model. What is the primary scaling advantage of this model?
options: It forces the coach to work more hours.
It leverages 'One-to-Many' delivery, increasing the hourly earning potential of the coach significantly.
It allows the coach to skip the 'Nutrition Education' part of the methodology.
It eliminates the need for any contract or legal agreement.
questions.explanation: The 'One-to-Many' model (group challenges/programs) is the cornerstone of scaling, as it allows the coach to serve 20-50+ people in the same time it would take to serve one, dramatically increasing revenue per hour.
